Primary Symptom: A 43-Year-Old Woman with Chronic Diarrhea, Hair Loss, and Nail and Skin Changes
Presentation of Case:
Dr. W.K. Claudia Wu: A 43-year-old woman was admitted to the Prince of Wales Hospital of the Chinese University of Hong Kong because of abdominal pain and diarrhea.
The patient had been well until 6 months before this admission, when colicky, diffuse abdominal pain developed. She also had nonbloody diarrhea that occurred up to 10 times daily. During the subsequent 6 months, the patient noticed de- creased appetite and weight loss of 5 kg. The symptoms did not abate, and her family encouraged her to seek medical evaluation.
On evaluation, the patient reported gradually darkening skin on the face, arms, and legs, as well as hair thinning and changes in the appearance of all the finger- nails and toenails during the previous 4 months. There was no nausea, vomiting, hematemesis, hematochezia, fevers, or night sweats.
The patient had a history of polycystic ovarian syndrome. Ten months before this admission, she had sought evaluation by a traditional Chinese medicine prac- titioner because of irregular menses. She was given a “homemade” traditional Chinese medicine that contained unknown ingredients. The patient took the rem- edy for 4 months and stopped taking it when the abdominal pain and diarrhea developed 6 months before this admission. She did not take other medications and had no known drug allergies. The patient lived with her husband and son in an urban area of Hong Kong, and she did not work outside the home. She did not vape or smoke cigarettes, and she did not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother and father were healthy; there was no family history of gastroenterologic, autoimmune, or hereditary diseases.
On evaluation, the temporal temperature was 37.2°C, the blood pressure 120/65 mm Hg, and the heart rate 85 beats per minute. The body-mass index (the weight in kilograms divided by the square of the height in meters) was 20. Examinations of the thyroid, heart, and lungs were normal. The abdomen was soft and nontender. There was no cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopa- thy. Moderate pitting edema was observed in the lower legs, up to the mid-calf. Dr. W.S. Agnes Chan: On dermatologic examination, the patient had patchy hair loss, with a large patch of alopecia at the vertex of the scalp; there was no scarring of the scalp (Fig. 1A). A hair-pull test (in which 40 to 60 strands of closely grouped hair are gently pulled, with more than 10% of hairs pulled out indicating a posi- tive result) was negative. There were symmetric brown macules over the lateral lower cheeks and malar regions of the face (Fig. 1B and 1C), and hyperpigmentation and diffuse brown-gray mac- ules were observed over the palms and the pal- mar aspects of the fingers (Fig. 1D and 1E). Onychodystrophy was present on all the finger- nails (Fig. 1E) and toenails. There was  onycholysis with distal separation of the nail plates from the nail beds, thinned nail plates, distal nail- plate crumbling, and onychomadesis with proxi- mal separation of the nail plates from the nail matrices (Fig. 1E and 1F).
Dr.  Wu:  The  blood  level  of  hemoglobin was 10.0 g per deciliter (reference range, 11.9 to 15.1) with a low mean corpuscular volume. The white- cell count, C-reactive protein level, and erythro- cyte sedimentation rate in blood were normal. The blood level of potassium was 2.9 mmol per liter (reference range, 3.5 to 5.0), ionized calcium 0.85 mmol per liter (reference range, 1.13 to 1.32), phosphate 0.52 mmol per liter (reference range, 0.72 to 1.43), and zinc 8.8 μmol per liter (refer- ence range, 10.7 to 18.0). The blood level of albu- min was 14 g per liter (reference range, 33 to 48). The protein level in a spot urine sample was normal. A stool culture showed normal enteric flora. Testing of a stool specimen for Clostridium difficile antigen and Shiga toxin was negative, as was a stool examination for ova and parasites. Other laboratory test results are shown in Table 1.

Differential Diagnosis: Autoimmune Diseases;Primary Adrenal Insufficiency;Heavy-Metal Poisoning;Cancer and Amyloidosis;Cronkhite–Canada syndrome (CCS)
Differential diagnosis content:
Dr. Jimmy C.T. Lai: I was involved in the care of
this patient and am aware of the final diagnosis.
This 43-year-old woman presented with weight
loss, chronic diarrhea, and multiple cutaneous
abnormalities, including changes to the nails,
hair loss, and skin hyperpigmentation that de-
veloped after the use of a traditional Chinese
medicine containing unknown ingredients. There
was laboratory evidence of malabsorption and
electrolyte disturbance, findings consistent with
protein-losing enteropathy. In constructing a
differential diagnosis, I will consider diseases
that cause protein-losing enteropathy and are
associated with dermatologic manifestations.
Autoimmune Diseases
Inflammatory bowel disease, systemic vasculitis,
systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and celiac
disease are autoimmune disorders that may cause
chronic gastrointestinal symptoms. Inflamma-
tory bowel disease, especially Crohn’s disease,
manifests with abdominal pain and chronic diar-
rhea that can be nonbloody. If there is small-
bowel involvement, malabsorption can occur,
with resultant electrolyte abnormalities, micro-
nutrient deficiencies, and weight loss, all of
which were seen in this patient. Extraintestinal
manifestations of Crohn’s disease that affect the
skin include erythema nodosum (characterized
by raised, erythematous, tender nodules appear-
ing mainly on the shins), pyoderma gangrenosum
(characterized by ulcerations with violaceous
edges appearing mainly on the legs), and Sweet’s
syndrome (characterized by a sudden onset of
painful nodules and fevers).1 This patient’s skin
changes are not consistent with these features of
Crohn’s disease.
A systemic vasculitis, such as Behçet’s disease,
or intestinal vasculitis can also lead to chronic
diarrhea, protein-losing enteropathy, and rashes.
However, the absence of a purpuric rash and of
oral, ophthalmic, or genital ulcers in this patient
makes this diagnosis unlikely.2

Key testing result:
Tests for autoimmune markers were negative, with the exception of a weakly positive antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody test with an antiproteinase 3 antibody level of 27.1 RU per milliliter. The anti–tissue transglutamin- ase IgA level was normal, as were the pituitary hormone levels. The blood level of free triiodo- thyronine was suggestive of euthyroid sick syn- drome.
A colonoscopy revealed nonspecific colitis, and numerous sessile polyps in clusters were observed throughout the entire colon (Fig. 2C). On white-light examination, the colonic polyps were hyperemic with a strawberry-like appear- ance (Fig. 2D). With narrow-band imaging, the pit patterns of the polyps were regular and stel- lar (Kudo classification type II) (Fig. 2E), a find- ing that was suggestive of inflammatory and non-neoplastic polyps.

Celiac disease can be associated with derma-titis herpetiformis, a rash characterized by itchy
papules and vesicles that are distributed sym-
metrically over the shoulders, elbows, and knees.
Because celiac disease is rare in the Asian popu-
lation6 and this patient’s skin findings would be
atypical of celiac disease, this diagnosis is also
unlikely.
Primary Adrenal Insufficiency
Primary adrenal insufficiency (also known as
Addison’s disease) is associated with a variety of
clinical manifestations, ranging from malaise
and weight loss to nonspecific gastrointestinal
symptoms, such as abdominal pain and diarrhea,
and can cause amenorrhea in female patients.
Cortisol insufficiency causes overproduction of
proopiomelanocortin and subsequent excessive
melanocyte-stimulating hormone, leading to some
degree of skin hyperpigmentation in most pa-
tients. This patient has weight loss, abdominal
pain, diarrhea, menstrual abnormalities, and
skin hyperpigmentation; however, Addison’s dis-
ease is not associated with hair loss or nail
changes.
Heavy-Metal Poisoning
The patient’s symptoms began soon after the
use of a traditional Chinese medicine with un-
known ingredients, which suggested the possi-
bility of heavy-metal poisoning caused by inges-
tion of either arsenic or lead.7-9 Arsenic poisoning
can cause skin hyperpigmentation but does not
typically result in hair and nail changes. Lead
poisoning can cause gastrointestinal symptoms
such as abdominal pain but not skin changes.
Chronic arsenic or lead poisoning may cause
other systemic symptoms, such as sensorimotor
polyneuropathy, but those symptoms are not
present in this patient.
Cancer and Amyloidosis
Cancer is always an important consideration in
the differential diagnosis of unintentional weight
loss. Colorectal cancer is possible in this patient,
despite her relatively young age and the absence
of risk factors. In particular, rectal cancer, the
incidence of which is rising among younger
adults,10,11 can cause diarrhea. Gastrointestinal
lymphoma can lead to chronic diarrhea and
protein-losing enteropathy, along with cutane-
ous involvement, although such manifestations
are uncommon.
Amyloidosis can affect many organs and has
a variety of manifestations. Systemic amyloido-
sis can cause rash, whereas amyloidosis that
affects the gastrointestinal tract can lead to
protein-losing enteropathy, malabsorption, and
constitutional symptoms.12 Amyloidosis is a rare
disease, and a biopsy of the affected sites would
be needed to confirm the presence of amyloid
deposition.
Other Diseases
Despite the absence of fever in this patient, in-
fection is a consideration. Tuberculosis is preva-
lent in the area where this patient lives, and
gastrointestinal tuberculosis can cause chronic
diarrhea and constitutional symptoms such as
weight loss. However, the absence of fevers and
night sweats, as well as the presence of hair and
nail changes, are not consistent with the diagno-
sis of tuberculosis.
The Cronkhite–Canada syndrome (CCS), a
rare, apparently noninherited hamartomatous
polyposis syndrome, may account for many of
the features of this patient’s clinical presenta-
tion. This syndrome was first reported by Dr.
L.W. Cronkhite, Jr., and Dr. W.J. Canada in 1955,13
and since then, only approximately 500 cases
have been reported worldwide.14,15 CCS is charac-
terized by the presence of multiple hamartoma-
tous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract
(apart from the esophagus), as well as multiple
cutaneous changes, including loss of the hair
and nails and hyperpigmentation of the skin.
Patients with CCS usually present with diarrhea
and protein-losing enteropathy as the dominant
gastrointestinal symptoms.14,16,17 Patients do not
necessarily have the full-blown cutaneous mani-
festations at presentation, and the severity of the
skin changes, which are reversible, may evolve
with underlying disease activity.18
There are no established diagnostic criteria
for CCS, and the diagnosis should be considered
when clinical characteristics compatible with
CCS, such as this patient’s gastrointestinal and
cutaneous symptoms, are present and when
other conditions are ruled out. Then, the diag-
nosis can be established if multiple hamartoma-
tous polyps are identified in the gastrointestinal
tract. This patient has many clinical features of
CCS, and an endoscopic examination would
most likely reveal multiple polyps that should be
resected for histologic examination.
